citation.article-title: Re-examination of the genus Acetobacter, with descriptions of Acetobacter cerevisiae sp. nov. and Acetobacter malorum sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Acetobacter cerevisiae sp. nov.
Acetobacter cerevisiae (ce.re.vi'si.a.e. L. fem. gen. n. cerevisiae of beer, referring to the source from which most strains have been isolated)
Cells are Gram-negative, ellipsoidal to rod-shaped, approximately 1.0 x 2.0-4.0 Î¼m in size, occurring singly, in pairs or occasionally in short chains.
Involution forms like swollen cells occur in some strains.
Colonies are beige to brown, round, regular to wavy, raised and smooth with a diameter of 0.3-0.5 mm on YPM agar.

Characterized by the combination of the following phenotypic features: 2-keto-D-gluconic acid is produced from D-glucose, 5-keto-D-gluconic acid is not produced from D-glucose, no growth with ammonium as the sole nitrogen source on ethanol as carbon source, no growth on maltose or methanol as carbon source (Table 3).
The range of G+C content of the DNA is 56.0-57.6 mol%.
The type strain is LMG 1625T (=DSM 14362T=NCIB 8894T=ATCC 23765T), which has a G+C content of 57.6 mol% and was isolated from beer (ale) in storage at Toronto, Canada (Kozulis & Parsons, 1958).
